Introduction to the HAL estimator

Nima Hejazi

2017-11-13

(Benkeser and van der Laan 2016), (van der Laan 2015), (van der Laan 2017)

Preliminaries

…

## 
## Attaching package: 'dplyr'
## The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
## 
##     filter, lag
## The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
## 
##     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union
# simulation constants



set.seed(467392)


n_obs <- 1000



n_covars <- 3





# make some training data


x <- replicate(n_covars, rnorm(n_obs))


y <- sin(x[, 1]) * sin(x[, 2]) + rnorm(n_obs, 0, 0.2)




# make some testing data


test_x <- replicate(n_covars, rnorm(n_obs))


test_y <- sin(x[, 1]) * sin(x[, 2]) + rnorm(n_obs, 0, 0.2)

Look at simulated data…


head(x)
##             [,1]       [,2]       [,3]
## [1,]  2.44102981  0.4670282  0.5659888
## [2,] -1.21932335  0.8894277 -0.1174505
## [3,] -0.40613567  0.3474353 -0.4692349
## [4,] -1.09760477 -0.1173214  0.8895520
## [5,]  0.23710498  1.8049389 -1.1283156
## [6,]  0.06810091  0.9301941  0.8971138

head(y)
## [1]  0.22550406 -0.66207651 -0.04202133 -0.05962337 -0.02333049  0.10083977

Using the Highly Adaptive LASSO


library(hal9001)
## hal9001: A fast and scalable Highly Adaptive LASSO
## Version: 0.0.5.1

Fitting the model

hal_fit <- fit_hal(X = x, Y = y)


hal_fit$times
# perform benchmarking


m_hal <- microbenchmark(unit = "s", times = 20,


  hal_fit_m <- fit_hal(X = x, Y = y)


)




# make plot


p_hal_times <- m_hal %>%




 dplyr::transmute(


     time_sec = time / 10^9



 ) %>%




 gather() %>%




 ggplot(., aes(x = key, y = value)) + geom_boxplot() + geom_point() +




   xlab("") + ylab("time (sec.)") + ggtitle("HAL9001") + theme_minimal()




p_hal_times



summary(m_hal)

…

Obtaining model predictions

# training sample prediction for HAL vs HAL9000


mse <- function(preds, y) {


    mean((preds - y)^2)


}




preds_hal <- predict(object = hal_fit, newdata = x)


mse_hal <- mse(preds = preds_hal, y = y)


mse_hal
oob_hal <- predict(object = hal_fit, newdata = test_x)


oob_hal_mse <- mse(preds = oob_hal, y = test_y)


oob_hal_mse

“Squashing” the model object

squashed_hal <- squash_hal_fit(hal_fit)




sq_preds <- predict(object = squashed_hal, newdata = x)


sq_oob_hal <- predict(object = squashed_hal, newdata = test_x)





cbind(preds_hal, sq_preds)



cbind(oob_hal, sq_oob_hal)

References

Benkeser, David, and Mark J van der Laan. 2016. “The Highly Adaptive Lasso Estimator.” In 2016 IEEE International Conference on Data Science and Advanced Analytics (DSAA). IEEE. doi:10.1109/dsaa.2016.93.

van der Laan, Mark J. 2015. “A Generally Efficient Targeted Minimum Loss Based Estimator.” bepress.

———. 2017. “Finite Sample Inference for Targeted Learning.” bepress.
